thread.title: Volcanic ash cloud again delays Air New Zealand, Jetstar and Virgin flights to and from Bali
thread.title_full: Volcanic ash cloud again delays Air New Zealand, Jetstar and Virgin flights to and from Bali

title: Volcanic ash cloud again delays Air New Zealand, Jetstar and Virgin flights to and from Bali
text:
Volcanic ash cloud again delays Air New Zealand, Jetstar and Virgin flights to and from Bali Last updated 11:49, August 5 2015 ANTARA FOTO/Reuters 
Volcanic ash and clouds are illuminated by lava from the crater of Mount Raung as seen from Botolinggo, Bondowoso, East Java, Indonesia 
Bali holidaymakers have been thwarted once again, as more volcanic ash from Mount Raung forces airlines to cancel or delay flights. 
Air New Zealand spokeswoman Kelly Kilgour said flight NZ245, scheduled to depart Auckland for Bali at 4.30pm on Wednesday, was delayed until 11am Thursday 6 August. 
"Due to forecast wind which is expected to affect volcanic ash conditions in Bali and the fact that our service was scheduled to arrive in darkness today's flight NZ245 from Auckland to Bali has been delayed," Kilgour said. 
Subject to favourable forecast conditions, NZ245 was scheduled to arrive into Denpasar on Thursday at 4.30pm, she said. 
Its late arrival would mean the return service from Bali to Auckland, NZ246, would also be delayed. 
Jetstar Australia has delayed two Bali flights on Wednesday morning, as winds push the ash cloud towards Denpasar airport. The airline cancelled four flights from Perth and Melbourne to Bali on Tuesday night. 
Virgin Australia has also delayed two flights from Australia to Bali. 
Jetstar and Virgin Australia have warned that conditions are likely to deteriorate throughout the day. 
The volcano has played havoc with flights since it began spewing corrosive, silica-based ash in early July, during the peak school holiday season. 
Mount Raung is one of the most active volcanoes on the Indonesian island of Java, about 140 kilometres west of Bali. 
Passengers are advised to check the status of their scheduled flights online. 
Stuff and Brisbane Times
